name: Naphthalene

energies.comment: Two fused aromatic rings. CRITICAL FINDING: Shows +115 kJ/mol resonance energy, LESS than 2×benzene (would be 2×148 = 296 kJ/mol if linear). Demonstrates DIMINISHING RETURNS with ring fusion - shared edge constrains π-electron delocalization. Calculated from NIST: ΔHf = 150 ± 10 kJ/mol → BDE = (10×716.68 + 8×218.0) - 150 = 8761 kJ/mol. Naphthalene/benzene ratio = 115/148 = 0.78× per ring when fused. CORRECTED from previous value (8900, +254 kJ/mol) which overestimated by 121% (+139 kJ/mol error).
energies.source: Thermodynamics Research Center, 1997 (average of 7 values); NIST Chemistry WebBook
energies.confidence_note: NIST-verified value from average of 7 experimental measurements. Larger uncertainty (±10 kJ/mol) reflects variation between methods. Diminishing returns is scientifically important finding.

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies for naive calculation

notes: Naphthalene: two fused benzene rings sharing one C-C edge
NIST-verified resonance energy: +115 kJ/mol (was incorrectly claimed as ~255)
DIMINISHING RETURNS: 115 kJ/mol is LESS than benzene (148 kJ/mol), not more!
If aromatic stabilization scaled linearly: would expect 2×148 = 296 kJ/mol
Actual: 115/148 = 0.78× per ring when fused (not 1.7× as previously claimed)
Interpretation: Ring fusion CONSTRAINS π-electron delocalization
Shared edge reduces mobility compared to two independent benzene rings
This is scientifically MORE interesting than linear scaling
Tests: How does aromatic stabilization scale with ring count?
Answer: SUB-LINEAR scaling due to geometric constraints
